div.p: Cyber Operations Stress Survey (COSS): Studying fatigue, frustration, and cognitive workload
Josiah Dykstra and Celeste Lyn Paul U.S. Department of Defense
AGENDA Motivation Stress Developing the Cyber Operations Stress Survey (COSS) Case Study at NSA Lessons Learned and Conclusions Questions
TACTICAL CYBER OPERATIONS Planned, structured set of activities with a specific goal in mind Speed and precision Highly trained workforce High-risk, high-reward work Ex: CTF, penetration testing
Amount of mental effort needed to use memory
Anxiety and annoyance over lack of control
Physical and mental feeling of tiredness

RELATED WORK Demanding jobs require attention, memory, and visual perception [7] High workload increases likelihood of errors, decreases performance [14] Burnout linked to mental exhaustion from stress [21] Shift work and hours worked contributed to high stress and burnout in cyber
warfare operators [3] Vigilance for (simulated) cyber events consistent with air traffic control [20] Stress from urgency to respond and hyper vigilance involved from not wanting to
STUDYING CYBER STRESS Small, inaccessible study population Sensitive work environments Few validated research methods
Subjective measure of stress Summative assessment Well-validated models Minimally invasive, in situ experience sampling
Fatigue: How awake or tired are you before the operation?
Very responsive, but not at peak.
A little tired, less than fresh.
Extremely tired, very difficult to concentrate.
FRUSTRATION & COGNITIVE WORK NASA Task Load Index (TLX)
Mental Demand: How mentally demanding was the operation?
Physical Demand: How physically demanding was the operation?
Time Demand: How hurried or rushed was the pace of the operation?
Overall Performance: How successful were you in accomplishing what you were asked to do?
Frustration Level: How insecure, discouraged, irritated, stressed, and annoyed were you?
Effort: How hard did you have to work to accomplish your level of performance?
Fatigue: How awake or tired are you before the operation?
Very responsive, but not at peak.
A little tired, less than fresh.
Extremely tired, very difficult to concentrate.
Fatigue: How awake or tired are you after the operation?
Very responsive, but not at peak.
A little tired, less than fresh.
Extremely tired, very difficult to concentrate.
Frustration Level: How insecure, discouraged, irritated, stressed, and annoyed are you?
Frustration Level: How insecure, discouraged, irritated, stressed, and annoyed were you?
Years experience Other duties as assigned
Personal Last day off Shift schedule Caffeine intake
Operation Operation type Team synergy Accomplish goal?
INTERNAL VALIDITY Cognitive Stress Factors N Df F p
Study RTLX SD COSS 44.55 28.1 Incident Response (Champion et al.) 56.94 21.4 Cyber Defense (Greenlee et al.) 51.94 14.2 Incident Escalation (Greenlee et al.) 40.04 11.6
Negative attitudes Value of sharing results Friendly competition
Contextual Factors Caffeine intake Team synergy
Limitations Subjective/self-report Affected by external factors
CONCLUSIONS COSS is an effective research instrument
Consider objective data for detection and prediction
Potential for real-time analysis and automated risk assessments
